description:
Mangifera indica, commonly known as the mango, is a species of tropical fruit tree that belongs to the genus Mangifera. It is native to the Indian subcontinent and is one of the most widely cultivated fruit trees in the world.

Mangifera indica is an evergreen tree that can grow up to 40 meters tall. The leaves are oblong or lanceolate in shape, with a leathery texture and a glossy green color. The flowers are small and yellowish-green, arranged in large, terminal panicles.

The fruit, the mango, is a drupe that can vary in size, shape, color, and flavor depending on the cultivar. The mango is typically oval or oblong in shape, with a thick, smooth skin that can range from green to yellow, orange, or red. The flesh is juicy, sweet, and fragrant, and surrounds a large, flat seed.

Mangoes are an important agricultural crop, with significant economic and cultural significance in many parts of the world. They are widely consumed fresh, used in various culinary preparations, and also processed into various products such as jams, chutneys, and juices.

Mangifera indica is adapted to tropical and subtropical climates and thrives in well-drained, fertile soils. It is an important source of nutrients, including vitamins A and C, as well as various antioxidants and phytochemicals that have been associated with health benefits.
